words.def: The phenomenon that a frequent measurement leads to "freezing" of the state.
words.name: Quantum Zeno effect

words.def: If the intrinsic properties (properties that can be measured but are independent of the quantum state, e.g. charge, total spin, mass) of two particles are the same, they are said to be (intrinsically) identical.
words.name: Intrinsically identical particles

words.def: If a system shows measurable differences when one of its particles is replaced by another particle, these two particles are called distinguishable.
words.name: Indistinguishable particles

words.def: Bosons are particles with integer spin (s = 0, 1, 2, ... ). They can either be elementary (like photons) or composite (such as mesons, nuclei or even atoms). There are five known elementary bosons: the four force carrying gauge bosons γ (photon), g (gluon), Z (Z boson) and W (W boson), as well as the Higgs boson.
words.name: Bosons

words.def: Fermions are particles with half-integer spin (s = 1/2, 3/2, 5/2, ... ). Like bosons, they can be elementary or composite particles. There are two types of elementary fermions: quarks and leptons, which are the main constituents of ordinary matter.
words.name: Fermions

words.def: A theorem connecting the classical mechanics and result dervied from Schrödinger equation.
